meeting_annotations.speaker: Tyler Robinson (Northern Arizona)
meeting_annotations.transcript: There's been this uh popular topic with like the W first mission of these data science challenges where a planet is created and then they noise it up to look as though W first did just observe it and they try to infer the properties. So you could imagine creating a database of of these low key planets, you can imagine creating a database of planets that have biology on them from barely getting along to more vibrant even than Earth and throw that at the community and say, can you tell us what's going on in these planets? And I think initially the answer is probably no, they can't sort these things out. Um but it it would be um it would be a clever thing to do well in advance of building your Luvar or your Habex.

meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, so the Loki planets are the ones that are trying to trick us into thinking that they have life. So Edwin's example of the destabilization of of the methane clathrates is going to try to trick us into thinking that there's life there um because there's methane showing up in the atmosphere but in reality it's it's a biological.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Victoria S Meadows (UW)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So they're false they're false positive planets.

meeting_annotations.transcript: It's fun, it's fun to talk about Loki right now because there's a TV series coming out I hear.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tori Hoehler (NASA Ames)
meeting_annotations.transcript: In in my case, Loki is my dog. So the idea of a Loki planet brings to mind a very specific visual. That's sometimes good and sometimes bad.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tori Hoehler (NASA Ames)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So um Ty what I what I liked about the notion that you just brought up, I think goes very much to what Silog is meant to be about. Um you know, creating the catalog of planets that you described. I don't think is something that you could do well without having the input that comes from um uh you know, people all across the scientific spectrum and and the full range of people that are represented here and um I think that's what this is meant to be about is finding that synergy.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Victoria S Meadows (UW)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So has anyone not reported out on their idea? Katherine. Okay.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tori Hoehler (NASA Ames)
meeting_annotations.transcript: You're muted.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katherine de Kleer (Caltech)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So this is going a kind of different direction because I work on more on moons than on planets, but I was thinking of of this in the context of the the icy satellites and if you have um let's say a habitable environment or even life in an ocean underneath an ice shell then the bio signatures or even habitability signatures um depend heavily on understanding the ice shell and what's going on in the ice shell, what the gradient of materials or chemicals is within the ice shell, what the gradient of temperatures is. And so this goes two directions, it's the downward direction and the upward direction. In the downward direction people use, you know, the chemicals that are on the surface of the ice um and say, oh if if those chemicals can get into the ocean then the ocean is habitable. Um but to make that inference you need constraints on whether those materials can diffuse or otherwise get through the ice shell. Conversely, if you want to try to detect bio signatures, you have to think about what the bio signatures are in the ocean and what products of those bio signatures could get to the surface and how you would distinguish them from exogenic material. And so there's this whole exchange problem that needs to be understood, what thermal gradient is required in the ice shell for example and what conditions like tidal heating or endogenic heat flow, what are the conditions that enable that thermal gradient. Um and these questions have definitely been explored for certain mission targets and especially in the context of mission studies, um but from my understanding, I think like a more broad and a little bit uh study with also with less of a specific agenda um is warranted for understanding how we would detect both habitability and um bio signatures.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nicolas Cowan (McGill)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I have a question about the icy moons. How long do we have to wait for them to be habitable in the exoplanet sense that that the ice will melt? Like as the sun gets brighter eventually the icy moons are going to have surface liquid water. How long is that going to last for? And like is it is it conceivable if you look at evolved stars that you could be seeing a planet that is now a water world that used to be an icy world or something? I mean we find planets around evolved stars. It'd be it'd be a funny day, right? For the dolphins that have a whole civilization under the ice and then one day the ice melts and they're like, woo! The whole world out there.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katherine de Kleer (Caltech)
meeting_annotations.transcript: That is a really interesting question.

meeting_annotations.transcript: I don't know.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jen Glass (she/her) - Georgia Tech
meeting_annotations.transcript: Is it ever going to get uh luminous enough for ours to our icy moons to actually melt?

meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah.

meeting_annotations.transcript: You only have five billion years, so we have that it's going to do it in that time.

meeting_annotations.transcript: Right.

meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay. At least have five billion years. That will certainly happen.

Um and so we can look at what's on the surface which is basically nothing but and and infer what is diffusing through the ice shell and use that as kind of a study to to make sure that your models for which chemicals can diffuse through the ice shell actually makes the right predictions for Enceladus where we have some constraints on the ocean chemistry.
